title: 3 Easy Ways to Reset an Air Conditioning Unit That’s Not Working

steps.title: Unplug your AC unit.
steps.content: Unplug your AC unit. Find the power cord that connects your external AC unit to the wall. Remove the cord from the outlet. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Plug the unit back in after 15 seconds.
steps.content: Plug the unit back in after 15 seconds. Wait at least 15 seconds before reconnecting the power cord to the outlet. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Press and hold the reset button for 3-5 seconds.
steps.content: Press and hold the reset button for 3-5 seconds. Look for a small, red button on the outside of your unit. If you can’t find it, check the user manual for your AC unit. Once you locate the button, hold it down for a few seconds, then release it. Voila! Your air conditioner has been reset and should start blowing cold air soon. [3] X Research source If you don’t have a paper copy of your manual, search for it online using the make and model. If your AC unit still isn’t working properly, reach out to a local HVAC technician. They’ll be able to diagnose and fix your air conditioner.

steps.title: Turn off your thermostat.
steps.content: Turn off your thermostat. Switch your thermostat off so it doesn’t kick on the AC while you’re doing the reset. If you can, cut power to the thermostat. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Cut power to your AC unit.
steps.content: Cut power to your AC unit. If your external AC unit has a built-in electrical disconnect, switch it off. Then, turn off the breaker for your AC unit. [5] X Research source You might find the breaker box on an exterior wall near your outdoor unit or on an interior wall in your basement, garage, or hallway. [6] X Research source Find the switch or switches that are labeled for your AC unit and turn them off. [7] X Research source A blown circuit breaker will be flipped outward (and that means you’ve found the culprit). Turn it fully to the off position.

steps.title: Restore power to the unit after 5 minutes.
steps.content: Restore power to the unit after 5 minutes. Give the unit a few minutes to discharge. If you switched off power to the AC unit at the electrical disconnect, turn that back on first. Then, flip the breaker or breakers to the on position. [8] X Trustworthy Source U.S. Department of Energy Official site for the U.S. Department of Energy, which provides resources related to energy safety, conservation, and efficiency Go to source

steps.title: Turn the thermostat back on after 1 minute.
steps.content: Turn the thermostat back on after 1 minute. Give your AC unit a chance to power back on. Then, restore power to the thermostat and set it to “cool.” [9] X Research source Some HVAC companies recommend waiting 30 minutes to turn your thermostat back on to give the unit more time to reset the internal breaker. If turning it back on after 1 minute didn’t fix the issue, try the process again but wait 30 minutes this time. If your AC still doesn’t blow cold air or makes any strange noises, contact an HVAC technician to troubleshoot and fix your system.

steps.title: Press the reset button if your unit has one.
steps.content: Press the reset button if your unit has one. Look for a reset button on the cord or the unit itself. If you find one, simply hold the button down for 5 seconds. Then, wait 10 minutes for your AC to reset. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Power off your AC unit if it doesn’t have a reset button.
steps.content: Power off your AC unit if it doesn’t have a reset button. If your unit has a power button, turn it off. Then, unplug the power cord. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Wait 5 minutes.
steps.content: Wait 5 minutes. Give your AC unit a little bit of time to discharge so it can fully reset. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Restore power to the unit.
steps.content: Restore power to the unit. Plug it back in, then turn it on. Problem solved! [13] X Research source
